quote: Blockchain is a decentralized, distributed, and often public, digital ledger that is used to record transactions across many computers so that any involved block cannot be altered retroactively without the alteration of all subsequent blocks.
The concept of a cryptographically secured chain of blocks dates back to 1991, described by Stuart Haber and W. Scott Stornetta.
Satoshi Nakamoto created the first widely known application of blockchain, the cryptocurrency Bitcoin, in 2008.
A 'block' on the blockchain holds a batch of valid transactions, a timestamp, and a cryptographic hash of the previous block.
The 'chain' refers to the sequential link between blocks, secured by the cryptographic hash.
Blockchain is synonymous with Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT).
The three main types of blockchain networks are Public, Private, and Consortium (or Hybrid).
Public blockchains (like Bitcoin) are open-source, permissionless, and transparent.
Private blockchains are permissioned and controlled by a single organization.
Consortium blockchains are controlled by a group of organizations, offering a balance of decentralization and control.
Immutability is a key feature, meaning data recorded on the blockchain cannot be easily changed or deleted.
Decentralization eliminates the need for a central authority, such as a bank or government, to validate transactions.
Consensus mechanisms (like Proof-of-Work or Proof-of-Stake) are used to validate new blocks before they are added to the chain.
Proof-of-Work (PoW) is the mechanism used by Bitcoin, requiring computational effort to solve complex math problems.
Proof-of-Stake (PoS) is a more energy-efficient alternative where validators are chosen based on the amount of cryptocurrency they 'stake'.
Ethereum, another major blockchain, transitioned from Proof-of-Work to Proof-of-Stake in 2022 (The Merge).
The first block in a blockchain is called the 'Genesis Block' (Block 0).
Blockchain is used for more than just cryptocurrencies, including supply chain management, voting, healthcare, and real estate.
Smart contracts are self-executing contracts with the terms of the agreement directly written into code, running on a blockchain.
The financial sector holds a significant portion of the total market share of blockchain technology.
Blockchain's transparency allows every network participant to view the shared ledger.
It is estimated that blockchain can reduce banks' infrastructure costs by up to 30%.
The business value of blockchain is expected to grow to $3.1 trillion by 2030.
Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs) are digital assets that use blockchain to prove unique ownership and authenticity.
Blockchain can enhance data security for healthcare records due to its tamper-proof nature.
A 51% attack is a theoretical scenario where one entity gains control of more than half of a blockchain's mining power or staking pool, potentially allowing them to manipulate the ledger.
The United States is one of the largest spenders on blockchain technology globally.
Blockchain technology is being integrated into the Metaverse for asset ownership and identity.
Some countries are exploring Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs) based on blockchain or DLT.
Blockchain transactions are recorded using cryptographic keysâ€”a public key (address) and a private key (password).
The speed of transactions (throughput) is a common challenge for public blockchains like Bitcoin.
Blockchain has the potential to streamline voting systems by making them secure and transparent.
Many governments have plans to invest in blockchain technology for various operations.
A blockchain is continuously growing as 'completed' blocks are added to it with a new set of recordings.
Blockchain is considered a foundational technology, capable of building new foundations for society and economics.
Nodes are the computers or devices that maintain a copy of the blockchain ledger and validate transactions.
Hashing is the process that converts input data of any size into a fixed-size string of characters, creating a unique 'fingerprint' for each block.
Changing even a single transaction in a block requires re-hashing that block and all subsequent blocks, which is computationally infeasible for a decentralized public chain.
Cryptocurrencies provide an incentive (rewards) for miners or validators to secure the network.
The technology promotes peer-to-peer transactions without the need for intermediaries.
The first commercial transaction using Bitcoin was for two pizzas, purchased for 10,000 BTC in 2010.
The global blockchain technology market is projected to reach hundreds of billions of dollars within the next decade.
Blockchain is being explored to reduce fraud in digital advertising by providing transparent transaction records.
The technology is revolutionizing content distribution by helping creators safeguard their rights.
Blockchain could help with digital identification for the billions of people worldwide who lack formal ID.
An advantage of blockchain is its high Byzantine fault tolerance, meaning it can still function even if some network nodes are compromised.
The use of 'tokenization' allows the value of an asset to be converted into a digital token on a blockchain.
Blockchain can expedite property trading by securely storing ownership records and eliminating protracted legal processes.
Layer 2 scaling solutions are being developed to increase the transaction capacity and speed of main blockchains (Layer 1).
As of a few years ago, more than 80 million blockchain wallets were registered globally for cryptocurrency use.
